annotation.TEXT: For now though, it's time for space biking! Easily the best part of this stage...even if your buster replacement is much weaker now (for reference, the meteors now take 4 hits instead of 1). Still, it's a lot more interesting than the vanilla Wave Man rider segment.

By this point, I should also mention the finickiness that is the slide. I'm a bit curious to hear what other people's experiences with this are. For me, sometimes the slide flat out doesn't work. I've heard that the input drops tend to happen if you're changing directions, but often times it acts up even when I'm facing the same way (then again, this all could just be an issue with my keyboard, so I'm reserving my judgement on this for now).

Pharaoh Man is a lot slower compared to his original counterpart (which kinda messes with the dodge timings, given the obvious). Strangely, he's not weak to Time Slow. Rather, it's the other way around. In those regards, I get that Quick Man makes more sense to be weak to the time-based weapon. On the other hand, Pharaoh's weakness takes "easy victory" to a whole new level.

Yes, enemies can follow you into the boss corridors (and even the boss rooms as well). Also, the ink immediately goes away upon charging the buster. Whether or not this interferes with the achievement you get for beating Splash Woman while inked, I'm not sure. Either way, she's still a relatively easy boss (even if you don't have the charged shot, seeing as she takes extra damage from basic shots).

Not gonna lie: While the layout of this stage is arguably one of the better ones in the game (even if it's really basic in a lot of regards), the overall look is...well, pretty boring. Granted, it eventually brings in some neat looking bits with a yellow sky/city in the background, but even then, the whole stage is mostly just neon purple.

Another good example of reverse difficulty structure: The first octopus has a ceiling lined with spikes, meaning you'd need to time your jumps carefully to hit it. This second one though, has a safe opening that allows you to hang back and jump as high as you want.
Fun fact: If you try to go back after turning that corner, you'll fall off the level and die. Evidentally, one of the dev's stated that this is an intentional feature, rather than a bug.
Oh, and another running theme is introducing gimmicks in hazardous ways (case in point: these Bubble Man platforms being introduced directly over a pit).
- 500 damage to gameplay involvement

Splash Woman's stage, for example, has a big problem with reverse difficulty syndrome. Pay close attention to how things are introduced: Often times the harder combinations of gimmicks and enemies are thrown at you first, and are then immediately followed up by easier variations.

The biggest thing to note on for now is...well, the 3D aspect itself, obviously. It actually does look pretty neat in a few spots, like when the game turns the whole screen to face another direction (it's less neat when it actively gets in the way of the gameplay, however. We'll talk more about that later). Aside from notable aesthetics, the game's overall content is largely lifted from past official games. That in itself isn't necessarily a bad thing. Rather, the stage design itself is where the problems start to creep up.

Well, here's something I didn't think I'd be playing for a while. Mega Man 2.5D originally started off as a concept back in 2009. Several years and a few demos later, the full game is upon us. Personally, I never really paid that much attention to the project before. Even so, I was still willing to give it a shot if anything came of it. The end result was...well, let's just say I'm gonna have a decent amount to talk about over the next few videos.

Time Slow is...interesting, but not for any of the intended reasons. On it's own, it's kinda "meh." There's very few spots outside of Quick Man's stage where it's actually useful. With that being said, there's a very fun glitch associated with both it and the charged shot (which will be on full display in the next video).

Star Crash has gotten a pretty significant buff, to the point where it's a strong contender for best weapon in the game. Instead of flaking out after just one hit, it now does continuous damage to anything it touches. Not to mention it also pierces shielded enemies and nullifies nearly every form of enemy projectile. The only downside is that it's incredibly slow when you throw it.

While I stupidly forget what ammo limitation is, let's talk about Time Man for a moment: This is just a straight up damage race. He'll jump from one end of the room to the other, slowing down time every other jump, and then firing off shots randomly either at ground or jump level. I haven't nailed down the timing (unintentional pun, I assure you), but it does seem possible - albeit, very annoying - to beat him with just the buster.

While Splash Woman's stage gave me a fair bit to talk about (mostly because of how poorly structured the difficulty curve was), the following stages sadly aren't as interesting. Star, Pharaoh, and Time are easily the most boring stages in the whole game. In those regards, I guess it's a good thing I'm getting them out of the way first. Trust me though, things will pick up really fast from part 2 onward.

Ok, this is kinda neat. The Sphinx is actually a removed mid-boss from the original MM4. I'm a little disappointed it doesn't use anything involving boulders though (as per the screen-shots from the original beta). As it stands, its attacks are pretty basic, to the point where you don't even need to use that back platform.

And now, all of a sudden, we're doing proper gimmick introduction (better late than never, I guess?). Either way, there's a collectible letter in this segment. This game has 4 of them, all spelling out the word "BOND." Collecting all of them will unlock a door much later on in one of the Wily stages, which in turn, leads to a fight with Bond Man. Here's a heads up: I'm not bothering with the letters. Almost all of them are placed in asinine locations (the one in Tornado Man's stage is especially rage-inducing), and you get nothing out of the whole ordeal aside from some achievements. All in all, it's not worth it (if you're really curious however, there's already a video of the Bond Man fight elsewhere at the time of writing this annotation).

Ignoring the creepy, dead-eye'd Roll back there, let's get into the basic run-down: The core mechanics of moving and firing are akin to Mega Man 3. You lack a charged shot at first, but the option to use it can be bought from the extra's menu (unlockables in this game are bought via points earned from achievements). Personally, I think this should have been a basic option from the start (like with Unlimited in subsequent updates). Then again, the initial lack of charged shot is far from this game's biggest problem.

Almost all the weapons function the same as their original counterparts, albeit with a few differences. Laser Trident's ammo has been bumped down from 56 to 28. In return however, you can now have three tridents on-screen instead of two.
